[In Deleted] The Deleted element is an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In Deleted] The Deleted element specifies whether the exception to the calendar item has been deleted.
[In Deleted] It[Deleted] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Deleted] A command request has a maximum of one Deleted child element per Exception element.
[In Deleted] A command response has a maximum of one Deleted child element per Exception element.
[In Deleted] The value of this element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In Deleted] An exception will be deleted when the Deleted element is included as a child element of the Exception element with a value of 1.
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] The DisallowNewTimeProposal<4> element is an optional element.
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] The DisallowNewTimeProposal<4> element specifies whether a meeting request recipient can propose a new time for the scheduled meeting.
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] It[DisallowNewTimeProposal] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] A command request is not required to include the DisallowNewTimeProposal element.
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] If this element[DisallowNewTimeProposal] is not included in a command request, then the default value for this element is 0 (FALSE).
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] A command response contains one DisallowNewTimeProposal element per response.
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] The value of the DisallowNewTimeProposal element is a boolean data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1.
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] The DisallowNewTimeProposal element can be ghosted.
[In DisallowNewTimeProposal] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In DtStamp] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the DtStamp element is an optional element.
[In DtStamp] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the DtStamp element specifies the date and time that the calendar item was created or modified.
[In DtStamp] It[DtStamp] is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In DtStamp] [DtStamp] As an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In DtStamp] [DtStamp] specifies the date and time that this exception was created.
[In DtStamp] A command request has a maximum of one DtStamp child element per Exception element.
[In DtStamp] A command response has a maximum of one DtStamp child element per Exception element.

[In DtStamp] If the DtStamp element is not specified as a child element of an Exception element, the value of the DtStamp element is assumed to be the same as the value of the top-level DtStamp element (section 2.2.2.16).
[In DtStamp] The DtStamp element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In DtStamp] The value of this element is a string data type, represented as a Compact DateTime ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.5).
[In Email] The Email element is a required child element of the Attendee element (section 2.2.2.3) that specifies the e-mail address of an attendee.
[In Email] It[Email] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Email] The value of this element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.
[In Email] A command request has only Email child element per Attendee element.
[In Email] A command response has only Email child element per Attendee element.
[In Email] The value of the Email element MAY be any arbitrary string.
[In Email] It is recommended that the string format adhere to the format specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.2.
[In EndTime] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the EndTime element is an optional element.
[In EndTime] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the EndTime element specifies the end time of the calendar item.
[In EndTime] The client SHOULD include the EndTime element in a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19).
[In EndTime] The EndTime element MUST be present in the response as a top-level element, even if the value of the AllDayEvent element (section 2.2.2.1) is 1.
[In EndTime] For details about server behavior when a calendar event is received that is missing either the StartTime element (section 2.2.2.40), the EndTime element, or both, see section 3.2.4.4.
[In EndTime] [the EndTime element ] As an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In EndTime] The EndTime element specifies the end time of the calendar item exception.
[In EndTime] A command request has a maximum of one EndTime child element per Exception element.
[In EndTime] A command response has a maximum of one EndTime child element per Exception element.

[In EndTime] If the EndTime element is not specified as a child element of the Exception element, the value of the EndTime element for the calendar item exception is assumed to be the same as the value of the top-level EndTime element.
[In EndTime] The EndTime element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In EndTime] The value of this element is a string data type, represented as a Compact DateTime ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.5).
[In Exception] The Exception element is an optional container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element.
[In Exception] The Exception element specifies an exception to the calendar item's recurrence pattern.
[In Exception] It[ Exception] is a child element of the Exceptions element (section 2.2.2.20).
[In Exception] It[ Exception] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Exception] A command request has between zero and 1000 Exception child elements per Exceptions element.
[In Exception] A command response has between zero and 1000 Exception child elements per Exceptions element.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:] Deleted (section 2.2.2.14): This element is optional.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:] ExceptionStartTime (section 2.2.2.21): One instance of this element is required.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:] Subject (section 2.2.2.41): This element is optional.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:] StartTime (section 2.2.2.40): This element is optional.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:] EndTime (section 2.2.2.18): This element is optional.
[In Exception] [The Exception element can have the following child elements:]airsyncbase:Body (section 2.2.2.7): This element is optional.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:]Location (section 2.2.2.25): This element is optional.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:] Categories (section 2.2.2.10): This element is optional.
[In Exception] [The Exception element can have the following child elements:]Sensitivity (section 2.2.2.39): This element is optional.
[In Exception] [The Exception element can have the following child elements:]BusyStatus (section 2.2.2.8): This element is optional.
[In Exception] [The Exception element can have the following child elements:]AllDayEvent (section 2.2.2.1): This element is optional.
[In Exception] [The Exception element can have the following child elements:]Reminder (section 2.2.2.36): This element is optional.
[In Exception] [The Exception element can have the following child elements:]DtStamp (section 2.2.2.16): This element is optional.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:] MeetingStatus (section 2.2.2.26): This element is optional.
[In Exception][The Exception element can have the following child elements:] Attendees (section 2.2.2.4): This element is optional.<5>
[In Exception] [The Exception element can have the following child elements:]AppointmentReplyTime (section 2.2.2.2): This element is optional in command responses.
[In Exception] It[AppointmentReplyTime] is not included in command requests.
[In Exception] ResponseType (section 2.2.2.38): This element is optional in command responses.
[In Exception] It[ResponseType] is not included in command requests.
[In Exception] OnlineMeetingConfLink (section 2.2.2.31): This element is optional in command responses.
[In Exception] It[OnlineMeetingConfLink] is not included in command requests.<8>
[In Exception] OnlineMeetingExternalLink (section 2.2.2.32): This element is optional in command responses.
[In Exception] It[OnlineMeetingExternalLink] It is not included in command requests.<9>
[In Exceptions] The Exceptions element is an optional container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element.
[In Exceptions] The Exceptions element specifies a collection of exceptions to the recurrence pattern of the calendar item.
[In Exceptions] It[Exceptions] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace and is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In Exceptions][The Exceptions element can have the following child element:] Exception (section 2.2.2.19): This element is optional.
[In ExceptionStartTime] The ExceptionStartTime element is a required child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19) that specifies the start time of the original recurring meeting.
[In ExceptionStartTime] It[ExceptionStartTime] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In ExceptionStartTime] A command request has only one ExceptionStartTime child element per Exception element.
[In ExceptionStartTime] A command response has only one ExceptionStartTime child element per Exception element.
[In ExceptionStartTime] The value of the ExceptionStartTime element is a string data type, represented as a Compact DateTime ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.5).

[In FirstDayOfWeek] The FirstDayOfWeek<10> element is a child element of the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35) that specifies which day is considered the first day of the calendar week for the recurrence.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] It[FirstDayOfWeek] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] A command request has a maximum of one FirstDayOfWeek child element per Recurrence element.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] A command response has a maximum of one FirstDayOfWeek child element per Recurrence element.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] This element disambiguates recurrences across localities that define a different starting day for the calendar week.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] The value of this element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] The value of the FirstDayOfWeek element MUST be one of the values[0,1,2,3,4,5,6] listed in the following table.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] [The value] 0 [means] Sunday.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] [The value] 1 [means] Monday.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] [The value] 2 [means] Tuesday.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] [The value] 3 [means] Wednesday.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] [The value] 4 [means] Thursday.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] [The value] 5 [means] Friday.
[In FirstDayOfWeek] [The value] 6 [means] Saturday.
[In Interval] The Interval element is an optional child element of the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35).
[In Interval] The Interval element specifies the interval between recurrences.
[In Interval] It[Interval] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Interval] A command request has a maximum of one Interval child element per Recurrence element.
[In Interval] A command response has a maximum of one Interval child element per Recurrence element.
[In Interval] The value of this element is an unsignedShort data type.
[In Interval] The value of this element is between a minimum value of 0 and a maximum value of 999.
[In IsLeapMonth] The IsLeapMonth element<11> is an optional child element of the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35).
[In IsLeapMonth] The IsLeapMonth element<11> specifies whether the recurrence of the appointment takes place on the embolismic (leap) month.
[In IsLeapMonth] It[IsLeapMonth] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In IsLeapMonth] A command request has a maximum of one IsLeapMonth child element per Recurrence element.
[In IsLeapMonth] A command response has a maximum of one IsLeapMonth child element per Recurrence element.
[In IsLeapMonth] This element only applies when the CalendarType element (section 2.2.2.9) specifies a calendar system that incorporates an embolismic (leap) month.
[In IsLeapMonth] Examples include lunisolar calendar systems such as Hebrew Lunar and Chinese Lunar.
[In IsLeapMonth] This element[IsLeapMonth] has no effect when specified in conjunction with the Gregorian calendar.
[In IsLeapMonth] The value of this element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In IsLeapMonth] The value of the IsLeapMonth element MUST be one of the values[0,1] listed in the following table.
[In IsLeapMonth] [The value] 0 [means] False.
[In IsLeapMonth] [The value] 1 [means]True.
[In IsLeapMonth] The default value of the IsLeapMonth element is 0 (FALSE).
[In Location] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the Location element is an optional element.
[In Location] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the Location element specifies the place where the event specified by the calendar item occurs.
[In Location] It[Location] is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In Location] [the Location element] As an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In Location] The Location element specifies the place where the event specified by the calendar item exception occurs.
[In Location] A command request has a maximum of one Location child element per Exception element.
[In Location] A command response has a maximum of one Location child element per Exception element.

[In Location] If the Location element is not specified as a child element of the Exception element, the value of the Location element for the exception is assumed to be the same as the value of the top-level Location element.
[In Location] The Location element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Location] The value of this element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.
[In Location] The top-level Location element can be ghosted.
[In Location] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In MeetingStatus] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the MeetingStatus element is an optional element.

[In MeetingStatus][As a top-level element of the Calendar class] the MeetingStatus element specifies whether the event is a meeting or an appointment, whether the event is canceled or active, and whether the user was the organizer.
[In MeetingStatus] It[MeetingStatus] is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In MeetingStatus] the MeetingStatus element is an optional child element of the Exception element.
[In MeetingStatus] The MeetingStatus element<12> specifies the status of the calendar item exception.

[In MeetingStatus] If the MeetingStatus element is not specified as a child element of an Exception element, the value of the MeetingStatus element for the exception is assumed to be the same as the value of the top-level MeetingStatus element.
[In MeetingStatus] The MeetingStatus element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In MeetingStatus] The value of this element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In MeetingStatus] The value of the MeetingStatus element MUST be one of the values[0,1,3,5,7,9,11,13,15,] listed in the following table.
[In MeetingStatus][The value 0 means] The event is an appointment which has no attendees.
[In MeetingStatus][The value 1 means] The event is a meeting and the user is the meeting organizer.
[In MeetingStatus][The value 3 means] This event is a meeting and the user is not the meeting organizer; the meeting was received from someone else.
[In MeetingStatus][The value 5 means] The meeting has been canceled and the user was the meeting organizer.
[In MeetingStatus][The value 7 means] The meeting has been canceled. The user was not the meeting organizer, the meeting was received from someone else.
[In MeetingStatus][The value 9 means] Same as 1 [The event is a meeting and the user is the meeting organizer.].
[In MeetingStatus][The value 11 means] Same as 3 [This event is a meeting and the user is not the meeting organizer; the meeting was received from someone else.].
[In MeetingStatus][The value 13 means] Same as 5 [The meeting has been cancelled and the user was the meeting organizer.].
[In MeetingStatus][The value 15 means] Same as 7 [The meeting has been cancelled. The user was not the meeting organizer, the meeting was received from someone else.].
[In MeetingStatus] The value of the MeetingStatus element is sent as an unsignedByte, but SHOULD be parsed by the client based on the following bit flags.
[In MeetingStatus] M - Meeting (1 bit): If set, the event is a meeting.
[In MeetingStatus] M - Meeting (1 bit): If not set, the event is an appointment.
[In MeetingStatus] R - Received (1 bit): If set, the user is not the meeting organizer and the meeting was received from someone else.
[In MeetingStatus] R - Received (1 bit): If not set, the user is the meeting organizer.
[In MeetingStatus] C - Cancelled (1 bit): If set, the meeting has been canceled.
[In MeetingStatus] C - Cancelled (1 bit): If not set, the meeting is active.
[In MeetingStatus] unused (variable): These bits are not used. MUST be zero.
[In MeetingStatus] unused (variable): [These bits are not used.] MUST be ignored.
[In MeetingStatus] The top-level MeetingStatus element can be ghosted.
[In MeetingStatus] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element is a child element of the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35) that specifies the month of the year for the recurrence.
[In MonthOfYear] It[MonthOfYear] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In MonthOfYear] A command request has a minimum of one MonthOfYear child element per Recurrence element if the value of the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) is either 5 or 6.
[In MonthOfYear] A command response has a minimum of one MonthOfYear child element per Recurrence element if the value of the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) is 5.
[In MonthOfYear] A command response has a minimum of one MonthOfYear child element per Recurrence element if the value of the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) is 6.
[In MonthOfYear] A command request has a maximum of one MonthOfYear child element per Recurrence element.
[In MonthOfYear] A command response has a maximum of one MonthOfYear child element per Recurrence element.
[In MonthOfYear] The value of this element[MonthOfYear] is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In MonthOfYear] The value of the MonthOfYear element MUST be between 1 and 12.
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element MUST be included in requests when the Type element value is either 5 or 6.
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element MUST be included in responses when the Type element value is 5.
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element MUST be included in responses when the Type element value is 6.
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element MUST NOT be included in requests when the Type element value is zero (0), 1, 3, or 6.
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element MUST NOT be included in responses when the Type element value is zero (0).
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element MUST NOT be included in responses when the Type element value is 1.
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element MUST NOT be included in responses when the Type element value is 3.
[In MonthOfYear] The MonthOfYear element MUST NOT be included in responses when the Type element value is 6.
[In Name] The Name element is a required child element of the Attendee element (section 2.2.2.3) that specifies the name of an attendee.
[In Name] It[Name] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Name] The value of this element[Name] is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.
[In Name] A command request has only one Name child element per Attendee element.
[In Name] A command response has only one Name child element per Attendee element.
[In NativeBodyType] The airsyncbase:NativeBodyType element is an optional element.
[In NativeBodyType] The airsyncbase:NativeBodyType element specifies how the body text of the calendar item is stored on the server.
[In NativeBodyType] It[NativeBodyType] is defined as an element in the AirSyncBase namespace and used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In NativeBodyType] The value of this element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In NativeBodyType] For details about the airsyncbase:NativeBodyType element, see [MS-ASAIRS] section 2.2.2.16.
[In Occurrences] The Occurrences element is an optional child element of the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35).
[In Occurrences] The Occurrences element specifies the number of occurrences before the series ends.
[In Occurrences] It[Occurrences] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Occurrences] A command request has a maximum of one Occurrences child element per Recurrence element.
[In Occurrences] A command response has a maximum of one Occurrences child element per Recurrence element.
[In Occurrences] The Occurrences element and the Until element (section 2.2.2.45) are mutually exclusive.
[In Occurrences] It is recommended that only one of these elements be included as a child element of a Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35) in a Sync command request.
[In Occurrences] The value of the Occurrences element is an unsignedShort, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA2/2].
[In Occurrences] The maximum value is 999.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] The OnlineMeetingConfLink element<13> is an optional element.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] The OnlineMeetingConfLink element<13> contains a GRUU for an online meeting.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] It[OnlineMeetingConfLink] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] The GRUU can be used by a user agent client (UAC) to connect to an online conference.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] The OnlineMeetingConfLink element is an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] The OnlineMeetingConfLink element specifies the GRUU for the exception.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] A command response has a maximum of one OnlineMeetingConfLink child element per Exception element.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] A command request MUST NOT contain the OnlineMeetingConfLink element.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] The value of the OnlineMeetingConfLink element is [either a GRUU as specified in [MS-SIPRE], or] an empty tag when included as a child of the Exception element.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] The value of the OnlineMeetingConfLink element is either a GRUU as specified in [MS-SIPRE], [or an empty tag when included as a child of the Exception element].
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] The OnlineMeetingConfLink element can be ghosted.
[In OnlineMeetingConfLink] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] The OnlineMeetingExternalLink element<14> is an optional element.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] The OnlineMeetingExternalLink element<14> contains a URL for an online meeting.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] It[OnlineMeetingExternalLink] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] The OnlineMeetingExternalLink element is an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] The OnlineMeetingExternalLink element specifies the GRUU for the exception.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] A command response has a maximum of one OnlineMeetingExternalLink child element per Exception element.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] A command request MUST NOT contain the OnlineMeetingExternalLink element.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] The value of this element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6 [or an empty tag when included as a child of the Exception element].
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] The value of this element is [a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6, or] an empty tag when included as a child of the Exception element.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] If a value for the OnlineMeetingExternalLink element exists, it SHOULD be a valid URL.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] The OnlineMeetingExternalLink element can be ghosted.
[In OnlineMeetingExternalLink] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In OrganizerEmail] The OrganizerEmail element is an optional element.
[In OrganizerEmail] The OrganizerEmail element specifies the e-mail address of the user who created the calendar item.
[In OrganizerEmail] It[OrganizerEmail] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace and is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In OrganizerEmail] The value of the OrganizerEmail element is a string ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6) in valid e-mail address format, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.2.
[In OrganizerEmail] The OrganizerEmail element can be ghosted.
[In OrganizerEmail] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In OrganizerName] The OrganizerName element is an optional element.
[In OrganizerName] The OrganizerName element specifies the name of the user who created the calendar item.
[In OrganizerName] It[OrganizerName] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace and is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In OrganizerName] The value of this element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.
[In OrganizerName] The OrganizerName element can be ghosted.
[In OrganizerName] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In Recurrence] The Recurrence element is an optional container ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.2) element.
[In Recurrence] The Recurrence element specifies the recurrence pattern for the calendar item.
[In Recurrence] It[Recurrence] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace and is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:]Type (section 2.2.2.43): One instance of this element is required.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:] Occurrences (section 2.2.2.30): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:]Interval (section 2.2.2.23): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:]WeekOfMonth (section 2.2.2.46): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:]DayOfWeek (section 2.2.2.13): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:] MonthOfYear (section 2.2.2.27): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:] Until (section 2.2.2.45): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:] DayOfMonth (section 2.2.2.12): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:] CalendarType (section 2.2.2.9): This element is optional in daily and yearly recurrences.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:] IsLeapMonth (section 2.2.2.24): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The Recurrence element can have the following child elements:] FirstDayOfWeek (section 2.2.2.22): This element is optional.
[In Recurrence] [The following limitations apply to the Recurrence element:]Multiple occurrences of the Recurrence elements, when specified on a single event, MUST NOT start on the same day.
[In Recurrence][The following limitations apply to the Recurrence element:] Multiple occurrences of the Recurrence element, when specified on a single event, MUST NOT overlap.

[In Recurrence] An exception that modifies the start date of an instance in the recurring series MUST occur on a date that is sometime after the end of the prior instance and before the start of the next instance in the recurring series.

[In Recurrence] The same[Multiple occurrences of the Recurrence element MUST NOT overlap. An exception that modifies the start date of an instance in the recurring series MUST occur on a date that is sometime after the end of the prior instance and before the start of the next instance in the recurring series. ] is true if the prior or next instance in the recurring series is defined as an exception by using the Exceptions element.
[In Recurrence] For more details about recurrence patterns, see [MS-OXOCAL] section 2.2.1.44.
[In Recurrence Patterns] Recurrence patterns for recurring calendar items are represented within the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35).

[In Recurrence Patterns] The Type element (section 2.2.2.43), which is a child of the Recurrence element, specifies the unit of the occurrence (daily, weekly, monthly, or yearly); additional child elements of the Recurrence element, such as Occurrences and DayOfWeek (section 2.2.2.13), are also used to fully define the recurrence pattern over time.
[In Recurrence Patterns] The following lists specify whether elements are required or optional for each value of the Type element.
[In Recurrence Patterns] It [the following list] also describes the relationship between the elements, and their meaning for different values of the Type element.
[In Recurrence Patterns] For all values of the Type element, the following elements are optional:

[In Recurrence Patterns][For all values of the Type element, the following elements are optional] Occurrences (section 2.2.2.30) [or Until (section 2.2.2.45)]. Either the Occurrences [or Until element] is required to specify an end date.

[In Recurrence Patterns][For all values of the Type element, the following elements are optional] [Occurrences (section 2.2.2.30) or] Until (section 2.2.2.45). [Either the Occurrences or] Until element is required to specify an end date.
[In Recurrence Patterns][For all values of the Type element, the following elements are optional] If neither value [Occurrences or Until element] is set, the event has no end date.
[In Recurrence Patterns][For all values of the Type element, the following elements are optional] IsLeapMonth (section 2.2.2.24).
[In Recurrence Patterns][For all values of the Type element, the following elements are optional] FirstDayOfWeek (section 2.2.2.22).
[In Recurrence Patterns] When the Type element is set to zero (0), meaning a weekly occurrence, the following elements are supported:
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to zero (0), meaning a weekly occurrence, the following elements are supported] Interval (section 2.2.2.23). Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to zero (0), meaning a weekly occurrence, the following elements are supported] DayOfWeek. Optional.

[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to zero (0), meaning a weekly occurrence, the following elements are supported] If the DayOfWeek element is not set, the recurrence is a daily occurrence, occurring n days apart, where n is the value of the Interval element.

[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to zero (0), meaning a weekly occurrence, the following elements are supported] If the DayOfWeek element is set, the recurrence is a weekly occurrence, occurring on the day specified by the DayOfWeek element, and the value of the Interval element indicates the number of weeks between occurrences.
[In Recurrence Patterns] When the Type element is set to 1, meaning a weekly occurrence, the following elements are supported:
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 1, meaning a weekly occurrence, the following elements are supported] Interval. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 1, meaning a weekly occurrence, the following elements are supported] DayOfWeek. Required.
[In Recurrence Patterns] When the Type element is set to 2, meaning a monthly occurrence, the following elements are supported:
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 2, meaning a monthly occurrence, the following elements are supported] Interval. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 2, meaning a monthly occurrence, the following elements are supported] DayOfMonth (section 2.2.2.12). Required.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 2, meaning a monthly occurrence, the following elements are supported] CalendarType (section 2.2.2.9). Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns] When the Type element is set to 3, meaning a monthly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported:
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 3, meaning a monthly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] Interval. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 3, meaning a monthly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] WeekOfMonth (section 2.2.2.46). Required.

[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 3, meaning a monthly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] If the DayOfWeek element is set to 127, the WeekOfMonth element indicates the day of the month that the event occurs.

[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 3, meaning a monthly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] If the DayOfWeek element is set to 62, to specify weekdays, the WeekOfMonth element indicates the nth weekday of the month, where n is the value of WeekOfMonth element.

[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 3, meaning a monthly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] If the DayOfWeek element is set to 65, to specify weekends, the WeekOfMonth element indicates the nth weekend day of the month, where n is the value of WeekOfMonth element.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 3, meaning a monthly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] DayOfWeek. Required.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 3, meaning a monthly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] CalendarType. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns] When the Type element is set to 5, meaning a yearly occurrence, the following elements are supported:
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 5, meaning a yearly occurrence, the following elements are supported:] MonthOfYear (section 2.2.2.27). Required.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 5, meaning a yearly occurrence, the following elements are supported:] Interval. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 5, meaning a yearly occurrence, the following elements are supported:] DayOfMonth. Required.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 5, meaning a yearly occurrence, the following elements are supported:] CalendarType. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns] When the Type element is set to 6, meaning a yearly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported:
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 6, meaning a yearly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] WeekOfMonth. Required.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 6, meaning a yearly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] DayOfWeek. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 6, meaning a yearly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] MonthOfYear. Required.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 6, meaning a yearly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] Interval. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns][When the Type element is set to 6, meaning a yearly occurrence on the nth day, the following elements are supported] CalendarType. Optional.
[In Recurrence Patterns] For examples of common recurrence patterns, see section 4.4.
[In Recurrence Patterns] Items that equate to the same sequence on the calendar can be represented by different recurrence patterns, as described in section 4.5.
[In Reminder] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the Reminder element is an optional element.
[In Reminder] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the Reminder element specifies the number of minutes before the calendar item's start time to display a reminder notice.
[In Reminder] It[Reminder] is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In Reminder] The Reminder element is an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In Reminder] The Reminder element specifies the number of minutes before a calendar item exception's start time to display a reminder notice.
[In Reminder] A command request has a maximum of one Reminder child element per Exception element.
[In Reminder] A command response has a maximum of one Reminder child element per Exception element.

[In Reminder] If the Reminder element is not specified as a child element of an Exception element, the value of the Reminder element for the exception is assumed to be the same as the value of the top-level Reminder element.
[In Reminder] The Reminder element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Reminder] The value of this element is an unsignedInt data type, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA2/2], [or an EmptyTag data type, which contains no value].<15>
[In Reminder] The value of this element is [an unsignedInt data type, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA2/2], or] an EmptyTag data type, which contains no value.<15>
[In ResponseRequested] The ResponseRequested<16> element is an optional element.
[In ResponseRequested] The ResponseRequested<16> element specifies whether a response to the meeting request is required.
[In ResponseRequested] It[ResponseRequested] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace and is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In ResponseRequested] The value of the ResponseRequested element is a boolean data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.1.
[In ResponseRequested] The ResponseRequested element can be ghosted.
[In ResponseRequested] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In ResponseType] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the ResponseType<17> element is an optional element.
[In ResponseType] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the ResponseType<17> element specifies the type of response made by the user to a meeting request.
[In ResponseType] The ResponseType<18> element is an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In ResponseType] The ResponseType<18> element specifies the type of response made by the user to a recurring meeting exception.

[In ResponseType] If the ResponseType element is not specified as a child element of an Exception element, the value of the ResponseType element for the exception is assumed to be the same as the value of the top-level ResponseType element.
[In ResponseType] A command request MUST NOT include the ResponseType element, either as a top-level element or as a child element of the Exception element.
[In ResponseType] A command response has a maximum of one top-level ResponseType element per response [and a maximum of one ResponseType child element per Exception element].
[In ResponseType] A command response has [a maximum of one top-level ResponseType element per response, and] a maximum of one ResponseType child element per Exception element.
[In ResponseType] The ResponseType element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In ResponseType] The value of this element is an unsignedInt data type, as specified in [XMLSCHEMA2/2].
[In ResponseType] The value of the ResponseType element MUST be one of the values[0,1,2,3,4,5] listed in the following table.
[In ResponseType] [The value 0 means]The user's response to the meeting has not yet been received.
[In ResponseType] [The value 1 means]Organizer. The current user is the organizer of the meeting and, therefore, no reply is required.
[In ResponseType] [The value 2 means] Tentative. The user is unsure whether he or she will attend.
[In ResponseType] [The value 3 means] Accepted. The user has accepted the meeting request.
[In ResponseType] [The value 4 means] Declined. The user has declined the meeting request.
[In ResponseType] [The value 5 means] Not Responded. The user has not yet responded to the meeting request.
[In ResponseType] The top-level ResponseType element can be ghosted.
[In ResponseType] For details about the use of ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In Sensitivity] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the Sensitivity element is an optional child element.
[In Sensitivity] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the Sensitivity element specifies the recommended privacy policy for the calendar item.
[In Sensitivity] It[Sensitivity] is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In Sensitivity] The Sensitivity element is an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In Sensitivity] The Sensitivity element specifies the recommended privacy policy for the calendar item exception.
[In Sensitivity] A command request has a maximum of one Sensitivity child element per Exception element.
[In Sensitivity] A command response has a maximum of one Sensitivity child element per Exception element.

[In Sensitivity] If the Sensitivity element is not specified as a child element of an Exception element, the Sensitivity element for the exception is assumed to have the same value as the value of the top-level Sensitivity element.
[In Sensitivity] The Sensitivity element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Sensitivity] The value of this element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In Sensitivity] The value of the Sensitivity element MUST be one of the values[0,1,2,3] listed in the following table.
[In Sensitivity] [The value] 0 [means] Normal.
[In Sensitivity] [The value] 1 [means] Personal.
[In Sensitivity] [The value] 2 [means] Private.
[In Sensitivity] [The value] 3 [means]Confidential.
[In StartTime] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the StartTime element is an optional element.
[In StartTime] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the StartTime element specifies the start time of the calendar item.
[In StartTime] The client SHOULD include the StartTime element in a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19).
[In StartTime] For details about server behavior when a calendar event is received that is missing either the StartTime element (section 2.2.2.40), the EndTime element, or both, see section 3.2.4.4.
[In StartTime] A Sync command response MUST contain one instance of the StartTime element.
[In StartTime] The StartTime element is an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In StartTime] The StartTime element specifies the start time of the calendar item exception.

[In StartTime] If the StartTime element is not specified as a child element of an Exception element, the value of the StartTime element for the exception is assumed to be the same as the value of the top-level StartTime element.
[In StartTime] The StartTime element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In StartTime] The value of this element is a string data type, represented as a Compact DateTime ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.5).
[In Subject] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the Subject element is an optional element.
[In Subject] As a top-level element of the Calendar class, the Subject element specifies the subject of the calendar item.
[In Subject] It[Subject] is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In Subject] The Subject element is an optional child element of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19).
[In Subject] The Subject element specifies the subject of the calendar item exception.
[In Subject] If the Subject element is not specified as a child element of an Exception element, the value of this element is assumed to be the same as the value of the top-level Subject element.
[In Subject] The Subject element is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Subject] The value of this element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.
[In Timezone] The Timezone element is an optional element.
[In Timezone] The Timezone element specifies the time zone of the calendar item.
[In Timezone] It[Timezone] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace and is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In Timezone] The value of the Timezone element is a TimeZone data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.4.
[In Type] The Type element is a required child element of the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35) that specifies the type of the recurrence.
[In Type] It[Type] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Type] A command request has only one Type child element per Recurrence element.
[In Type] A command response has only one Type child element per Recurrence element.
[In Type] The value of this element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In Type] The value of the Type element MUST be one of the values[0,1,2,3,5,6] listed in the following table.
[In Type] [The value 0 means] Recurs daily.
[In Type] [The value 1 means] Recurs weekly.
[In Type] [The value 2 means] Recurs monthly.
[In Type] [The value 3 means] Recurs monthly on the nth day.
[In Type] [The value 5 means] Recurs yearly.
[In Type] [The value 6 means] Recurs yearly on the nth day.
[In UID] The UID element is an optional element in the command request.
[In UID] The UID element specifies a random hexadecimal ID generated by the client when the calendar item is created.
[In UID] It[UID] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace and is used in ActiveSync command requests and responses as specified in section 2.2.2.
[In UID] The value of the UID element is a string data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.
[In UID] The maximum length of this element is 300 characters.
[In UID] If the UID element is not included in the command request, the server creates a value and includes it in the command response.
[In Until] The Until element is an optional child element of the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35).
[In Until] The Until element specifies the end date and time of the recurrence.
[In Until] It[Util] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In Until] A command request has a maximum of one Until child element per Recurrence element.
[In Until] A command response has a maximum of one Until child element per Recurrence element.
[In Until] The Until element and the Occurrences element (section 2.2.2.30) are mutually exclusive.
[In Until] It is recommended that only one of these elements be included as a child element of a Recurrence element in a Sync command request.
[In Until] The value of the Until element is a string data type, represented as a Compact DateTime ([MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.5).

[In WeekOfMonth] The WeekOfMonth element is a child element of the Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35) that specifies either the week of the month or the day of the month for the recurrence, depending on the value of the Type element.
[In WeekOfMonth] It[WeekOfMonth] is defined as an element in the Calendar namespace.
[In WeekOfMonth] A command request has a minimum of one WeekOfMonth child element per Recurrence element when the value of the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) is either 3 or 6.
[In WeekOfMonth] A command response has a minimum of one WeekOfMonth child element per Recurrence element when the value of the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) is 3.
[In WeekOfMonth] A command response has a minimum of one WeekOfMonth child element per Recurrence element when the value of the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) is 6.
[In WeekOfMonth] A command request has a maximum of one WeekOfMonth child element per Recurrence element.
[In WeekOfMonth] A command response has a maximum of one WeekOfMonth child element per Recurrence element.
[In WeekOfMonth] The value of this element is an unsignedByte data type, as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.7.
[In WeekOfMonth] The value of the WeekOfMonth element MUST be between 1 and 5.
[In WeekOfMonth] The value of 5 specifies the last week of the month.
[In WeekOfMonth] The WeekOfMonth element MUST only be included in requests when the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) value is either 3 or 6.
[In WeekOfMonth] The WeekOfMonth element MUST only be included in responses when the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) value is 3.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCAL_R478113.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In WeekOfMonth] The WeekOfMonth element MUST only be included in responses when the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) value is 6.
ns1:Requirement.ns1:VerificationComment: Partially verified by derived requirement: MS-ASCAL_R478114.

ns1:Requirement.ns1:Description: [In WeekOfMonth] The WeekOfMonth element MUST be included in responses when the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) value is 3.
[In WeekOfMonth] The WeekOfMonth element MUST be included in responses when the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) value is 6.

[In WeekOfMonth] When the Type element is set to 3, to indicate monthly on the nth of the month, the WeekOfMonth element MAY be used to specify day of the month on which the event occurs. For more details, see section 2.2.2.35.1.
[In Groups] The following table summarizes the set of common XML schema group definitions defined by this specification.
[In Groups] XML schema groups that are specific to a particular operation are described with the operation.
[In Groups] TopLevelSchemaProps (section 2.2.3.1) Identifies the elements that are part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group.
[In TopLevelSchemaProps] The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] Timezone, as specified in section 2.2.2.42
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] StartTime, as specified in section 2.2.2.40
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] EndTime, as specified in section 2.2.2.18
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] Subject, as specified in section 2.2.2.41
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] Location, as specified in section 2.2.2.41
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] Reminder, as specified in section 2.2.2.36
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] AllDayEvent, as specified in section 2.2.2.1
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] BusyStatus, as specified in section 2.2.2.8
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] Recurrence, as specified in section 2.2.2.35
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] Sensitivity, as specified in section 2.2.2.39
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] DtStamp, as specified in section 2.2.2.16
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] Attendees, as specified in section 2.2.2.4
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] Categories, as specified in section 2.2.2.10
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] MeetingStatus, as specified in section 2.2.2.26
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] OrganizerName, as specified in section 2.2.2.34
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] OrganizerEmail, as specified in section 2.2.2.33
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] UID, as specified in section 2.2.2.44
[In TopLevelSchemaProps][The TopLevelSchemaProps group identifies the following elements as being part of the TopLevelSchemaProps group:] DisallowNewTimeProposal, as specified in section 2.2.2.15

[In TopLevelSchemaProps] The TopLevelSchemaProps group is used by the ItemOperations command request specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8.
[In Abstract Data Model] This section describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol.
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.
[In Abstract Data Model] This document [MS-ASCAL]does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model as long as their external behavior is consistent with that described in this document.
[In Abstract Data Model] Calendar class: A structured XML text block that adheres to the XML schema definition specified in section 2.2.
[In Abstract Data Model] : It [Calendar class] is returned by the server to the client as part of a full XML response to the client command requests that are specified in section 3.1.5.
[In Abstract Data Model] Calendar class data is included in command requests sent to the server when calendar items need to be retrieved, searched, or synchronized.
[In Abstract Data Model] Command request: A WBXML-formatted message that adheres to the command schemas specified in [MS-ASCMD].

[In Synchronizing Calendar Data Between Client and Server] A client initiates synchronization of Calendar class data with the server by sending a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19) to the server.
[In Searching a Server for Calendar Data] A client searches for Calendar class data on the server by sending a Search command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.14) to the server.

[In Requesting Details for One or More Calendar Items] A client requests Calendar class data for one or more individual calendar items by sending an ItemOperations command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8) to the server that contains one or more itemoperations:Fetch elements ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.63.1).

[In Creating a New Meeting Request] When a user creates a meeting on the client, the client creates a meeting request within the user’s calendar, and sends e-mail with the properly formatted meeting requests to the specified attendees.

[In Creating a New Meeting Request] As the server receives the attendee responses, the organizer receives updates to the meeting request within the Sync command response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19).
[In Creating a New Meeting Request] [MS-ASCMD] section 4.15.3 specifies an example that demonstrates a meeting request included in a Sync command response.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] The following sections specify how elements of the Calendar class are used in the context of specific ActiveSync commands.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] Command details are specified in [MS-ASCMD].

[In ItemOperations Command Request] A client uses an ItemOperations command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8) that contains one or more itemoperations:Fetch elements ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.63.1) to retrieve data from the server for one or more specific calendar items.
[In ItemOperations Command Request] Any of the elements that belong to the Calendar class, as specified in section 2.2.2, can be included in an ItemOperations command request.

[In ItemOperations Command Request] Top-level Calendar class elements, as specified in section 2.2.2, MUST be transmitted as child elements of the itemoperations:Schema element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.145).
[In ItemOperations Command Request] For more details about the ItemOperations command, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8.
[In Search Command Request] A client uses the Search command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.14) to retrieve Calendar class items from the server that match the criteria specified by the client.
[In Search Command Request] Elements that belong to the Calendar class, as specified in section 2.2.2, MUST NOT be included in a Search command request.
[In Search Command Request] For more details about the Search command, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.14.

[In Sync Command Request] A client uses the Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19) to synchronize its Calendar class items for a specified user with the calendar items that are currently stored by the server.
[In Sync Command Request] Any of the elements that belong to the Calendar class, as specified in section 2.2.2, can be included in a Sync command request.

[In Sync Command Request] Top-level Calendar class elements, as specified in section 2.2.2, can be transmitted as child elements of the airsync:ApplicationData element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.11) within either an airsync:Add element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.7.2) or an airsync:Change element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.24).
[In Sync Command Request] Top-level Calendar class elements can be transmitted as child elements of the airsync:Supported element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164) in order to support ghosted elements.
[In Sync Command Request] A specific subset of the Calendar class elements is required in this instance.
[In Sync Command Request] The full list is specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In Sync Command Request] For more details about the Sync command, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19.

[In Indicating Deleted Elements in Exceptions] If an element in a recurring calendar item has been deleted in an Exception element (section 2.2.2.19), the client sends an empty tag for this element to remove the inherited value from the server.

[In Indicating Deleted Elements in Exceptions] For example, if the Location element (section 2.2.2.25) has been deleted for an exception, the client sends an empty Location element in a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19).
[In Indicating Deleted Elements in Exceptions] A client cannot remove an inherited element value from an exception if that property is ghosted.

[In Omitting Ghosted Properties from a Sync Change Request] When the client sends a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19) to the server that contains a nonzero airsync:SyncKey element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.166.4) value, the client uses the airsync:Supported element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164) within the Sync command request to specify which properties are not ghosted.

[In Omitting Ghosted Properties from a Sync Change Request] In subsequent Sync command requests, the client includes only the set of airsync:Supported elements in the Sync command request's airsync:Change element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.24).
[In Omitting Ghosted Properties from a Sync Change Request] For more details about ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In Abstract Data Model] This section[3.2.1] describes a conceptual model of possible data organization that an implementation maintains to participate in this protocol[MS-ASCAL].
[In Abstract Data Model] The described organization is provided to facilitate the explanation of how the protocol behaves.
[In Abstract Data Model] This document[MS-ASCAL] does not mandate that implementations adhere to this model as long as their external behavior is consistent with that described in this document.
[In Abstract Data Model] Calendar class: a structured XML text block that adheres to the XML schema definition specified in section 2.2.
[In Abstract Data Model] It[Calendar class] is returned by the server to the client as part of a full XML response to the client command requests that are specified in section 3.1.5.
[In Abstract Data Model] Calendar class data is included in command requests sent to the server when calendar items need to be retrieved, searched, or synchronized.
[In Abstract Data Model] Command response: A WBXML-formatted message that adheres to the command schemas specified in [MS-ASCMD].
[In Synchronizing Calendar Data Between Client and Server] Synchronization of Calendar class data between client and server is initiated by the client, as specified in section 3.1.4.1.
[In Synchronizing Calendar Data Between Client and Server] The server responds with a Sync command response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19).
[In Searching for Calendar Data] Searching for Calendar class data is initiated by the client, as specified in section 3.1.4.2.
[In Searching for Calendar Data] The server responds with a Search command response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.14).
[In Retrieving Details for One or More Calendar Items] Retrieval of Calendar class data for one or more individual calendar items is initiated by the client, as specified in section 3.1.4.3.
[In Retrieving Details for One or More Calendar Items] The server responds with an ItemOperations command response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8).

[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] If the server receives a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19) to add a calendar event that is missing either the StartTime element (section 2.2.2.40), the EndTime element (section 2.2.2.18), or both, the server attempts to substitute values based on the current time, rounded to the nearest half hour, for the missing values.

[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] For example, if the server receives a Sync command request at 18:03 to add a new calendar event, the server rounds the current time to 18:30.
[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] The server sets the StartTime and EndTime elements as specified in the following table.

[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] If StartTime and EndTime are both absent the server sets the value of the StartTime element to the rounded current time, and sets the value of the EndTime element to the rounded current time plus 30 minutes.

[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] If StartTime is absent and EndTime is in the past the server includes a Status element with a value of 6 in the response, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16, indicating an error occurred.

[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] If StartTime is absent and EndTime is in the future the server sets the value of the StartTime element to the rounded current time and sets the value of the EndTime element to the value of the EndTime element in the request.

[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] If the rounded current time is after the end time, the server includes a Status element with a value of 6 in the response, indicating an error occurred.

[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] If StartTime is in the past and EndTime is absent the server sets the value of the StartTime element to the value of the StartTime element in the request and sets the value of the EndTime element to the rounded current time.

[In Creating Calendar Events when the StartTime Element or EndTime Element is Absent] If StartTime is in the future and EndTime is absent the server includes a Status element with a value of 6 in the response, indicating an error occurred.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules][The following information pertains to all command responses:] A server MUST recognize when the value of the Email element is not formatted as specified in [MS-ASDTYPE] section 2.6.2 and MUST replace it with suitable placeholder text.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules][The following information pertains to all command responses:] If no action has been taken on a meeting request, the server MUST NOT include the AppointmentReplyTime element as a top-level element in a command response.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules][The following information pertains to all command responses:] If a meeting request exception has not been accepted, the server MUST NOT include the AppointmentReplyTime element as a child element of the Exception element in a command response.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules][The following information pertains to all command responses:] If a meeting request exception has not been tentatively accepted, the server MUST NOT include the AppointmentReplyTime element as a child element of the Exception element in a command response.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules][The following information pertains to all command responses:] The server MUST return a FirstDayOfWeek element when the value of the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) is 1.

[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules][The following information pertains to all command responses:] If the FirstDayOfWeek element is not included in the client request, the server SHOULD identify the first day of the week for any recurrence according to the preconfigured options of the user creating the calendar item.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] The following sections specify how elements of the Calendar class are used in the context of specific ActiveSync commands.
[In Message Processing Events and Sequencing Rules] [ActiveSync commands] Command details are specified in [MS-ASCMD].

[In ItemOperations Command Response] When a client uses an ItemOperations command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8), as specified in section 3.1.5.1, to retrieve data from the server for one or more specific calendar items, the server responds with an ItemOperations command response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8).
[In ItemOperations Command Response] Any of the elements that belong to the Calendar class, as specified in section 2.2.2, can be included in an ItemOperations command response.

[In ItemOperations Command Response] If an airsync:Schema element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.145) is included in the ItemOperations command request, the elements returned in the ItemOperations command response MUST be restricted to the elements that were included as child elements of the airsync:Schema element in the command request.

[In ItemOperations Command Response] Top-level Calendar class elements, as specified in section 2.2.2, MUST be returned as child elements of the itemoperations:Properties element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.128) in the ItemOperations command response.
[In ItemOperations Command Response] For more details about the ItemOperations command, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.8.

[In Search Command Response] When a client uses the Search command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.14), as specified in section 3.1.5.2, to retrieve Calendar class items from the server that match the criteria specified by the client, the server responds with a Search command response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.14).
[In Search Command Response] Any of the elements that belong to the Calendar class, as specified in section 2.2.2, can be included in a Search command response.
[In Search Command Response] Top-level Calendar class elements MUST be returned as child elements of the search:Properties element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.128) in the Search command response.
[In Search Command Response] For more details about the Search command, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.14.

[In Sync Command Response] When a client uses the Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19), as specified in section 3.1.5.3, to synchronize its Calendar class items for a specified user with the calendar items that are currently stored by the server, the server responds with a Sync command response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19).

[In Sync Command Response] Top-level Calendar class elements, as specified in section 2.2.2, can be included in a Sync command response as child elements of the airsync:ApplicationData element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.11) within either an airsync:Add element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.7.2) or an airsync:Change element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.24) in the Sync command response.

[In Sync Command Response] If one or more properties of an exception for recurring calendar item (that is, any child elements of the Exception element (section 2.2.2.19)) have been deleted, the server MUST transmit an empty element in the Sync command response to indicate that this property is not inherited from the recurrence.

[In Sync Command Response] If both the Occurrences element (section 2.2.2.30) and the Until element (section 2.2.2.45) are included in a Sync command request, then the server MUST respect the value of the Occurrences element [and ignore the value of the Until element].

[In Sync Command Response] If both the Occurrences element (section 2.2.2.30) and the Until element (section 2.2.2.45) are included in a Sync command request, then the server MUST [respect the value of the Occurrences element and] ignore the value of the Until element.

[In Sync Command Response][The Sync command response contains an airsync:Status element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16) with a value of 6 in the following cases:] A command request has more than one CalendarType element (section 2.2.2.9) per Recurrence element (section 2.2.2.35) when the Type element (section 2.2.2.43) value is 2, 3, 5, or 6.

[In Sync Command Response][The Sync command response contains an airsync:Status element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16) with a value of 6 in the following cases:] The CalendarType element is set to one of the following values in the request: 13, 16, 17, 18, 19, 21, 22, or 23.

[In Sync Command Response][The Sync command response contains an airsync:Status element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16) with a value of 6 in the following cases:] The value of the FirstDayOfWeek element (section 2.2.2.22) is outside the range 0 (zero) through 6 (inclusive).

[In Sync Command Response][The Sync command response contains an airsync:Status element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16) with a value of 6 in the following cases:] The EndTime element (section 2.2.2.18) is included in a request and the StartTime element is not included in the request.

[In Sync Command Response][The Sync command response contains an airsync:Status element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16) with a value of 6 in the following cases:] The DayOfMonth element (section 2.2.2.12) is included in a request when the value of the Type element is not 2 or 5.

[In Sync Command Response][The Sync command response contains an airsync:Status element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16) with a value of 6 in the following cases:] The DayOfWeek element (section 2.2.2.13) is included in a request when the value of the Type element is not 0 (zero), 1, 3, or 6.

[In Sync Command Response][The Sync command response contains an airsync:Status element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16) with a value of 6 in the following cases:] The MonthOfYear element (section 2.2.2.27) is included in a request when the value of the Type element is not 5 or 6.

[In Sync Command Response][The Sync command response contains an airsync:Status element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.162.16) with a value of 6 in the following cases:] The WeekOfMonth element (section 2.2.2.46) is included in a request when the value of the Type element is not 3 or 6.
[In Sync Command Response] For more details about the Sync command, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19.
[In Removing Exceptions] If an Exceptions element (section 2.2.2.20) is not specified in a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19), then any exceptions previously defined are unchanged.

[In Removing Exceptions] [If an Exceptions element (section 2.2.2.20) is not specified in a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19.2), then] any exceptions previously defined are unchanged, even if the client included the Exceptions element as a child of the Supported element, as specified in [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.
[In Removing Exceptions] If a particular Exception element (section 2.2.2.19) is excluded in a Sync command request, then that particular exception remains unchanged.

[In Indicating Deleted Elements in Exceptions] If an element of a recurring calendar item has been deleted in an Exception element (section 2.2.2.19), the server MUST send an empty tag for this element in the Sync command response ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19).

[In Indicating Deleted Elements in Exceptions] For example, if the Location element (section 2.2.2.25) has been deleted for an exception, the server sends an empty Location element in the Sync command response.

[In Omitting Ghosted Properties from a Sync Change Request] When the client sends a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19) to the server that contains a nonzero airsync:SyncKey element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.166.4) value, the client uses the airsync:Supported element within the Sync command request to specify which properties are not ghosted.

[In Omitting Ghosted Properties from a Sync Change Request] In subsequent Sync command requests, the client includes only these elements[airsync:SyncKey,airsync:Supported] in the Sync command request's airsync:Change element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.24).
[In Omitting Ghosted Properties from a Sync Change Request] Ghosted elements are not sent to the server.

[In Omitting Ghosted Properties from a Sync Change Request] [When the client sends a Sync command request ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.2.19.1) to the server that contains a nonzero airsync:SyncKey element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.166.4) value, the client uses the airsync:Supported element within the Sync command request to specify which properties are not ghosted. In subsequent Sync command requests, the client includes only these elements in the Sync command request's airsync:Change element ([MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.24). Ghosted elements are not sent to the server.]Instead of deleting these excluded properties, the server preserves their previous value.
[In Omitting Ghosted Properties from a Sync Change Request] For more details about ghosted properties, see [MS-ASCMD] section 2.2.3.164.

[In Appendix B: Product Behavior] Unless otherwise specified, the term MAY implies that the product does not follow the prescription.
